Research Paper Upgrading the performance of syngas to ethanol via Mn modified Rh-based catalyst Maosheng Yang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Investigation a b 1 Yang Feng Writing – original draft Methodology Data curation a 1 Jungang Wang Writing – original draft Methodology Conceptualization a ⁎ Zhongyi Ma Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Congbiao Chen Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Wei Zhang Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Shupeng Guo Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Hongjuan Xi Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Zhancheng Ma Writing – review & editing Validation Resources Investigation a Bo Hou Writing – original draft Methodology Conceptualization a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory for High Efficiency and Low Carbon Utilization of Coal, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory for High Efficiency and Low Carbon Utilization of Coal Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China aState Key Laboratory for High Efficiency and Low Carbon Utilization of Coal, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Significant strides have been undertaken to catalyze the production of ethanol from syngas, yet the challenge remains in developing catalysts that simultaneously exhibit high activity and selectivity. In this study, we designed a high-performance Rh-Mn catalyst. The CO conversion of finally screened 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is 51.8 %, and the total alcohol selectivity and ethanol yield are 72.1 % and 24.1 % respectively. This is the highest ethanol yield reported to date for Rh-based catalysts. Additionally, this catalyst also kept good stability. The outstanding performance is attributed to the fact that Mn facilitates the formation of Rh+ active sites, the process of CO insertion, and the generation of CH3CHO and CH3CO species—critical intermediates in ethanol production. In contrast, the unpromoted 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst showed poor ethanol selectivity and mainly produced the Rh0 species, whereas the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst with the addition of Mn showed an increase in total alcohol and ethanol selectivity of 26.5 % and 31.3 %, respectively, as well as a reduction in CO2 of 50.4 %. In addition, we elucidated the CO2 generation and conversion pathways in the syngas to ethanol process, which is important for the effective utilization of carbon resources. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethanol synthesis RhMn Promoter CO insertion CO2 reduction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethanol has received extensive attention as an attractive alternative energy source [1–3]. Among the many ethanol synthesis ways, the direct syngas conversion to ethanol (STE) is considered to a promising technology at present. Firstly, ethanol production can utilize all kinds of sources including coal, biomass, natural gas, and CO2 [4–6]; secondly, the preparation process is simple and ethanol can be obtained directly from syngas, avoiding complicated intermediate steps [7,8]. Although the direct production of ethanol from syngas is currently the most promising method, it has not been widely used in industrial applications so far [9,10]. The main reason is that most current catalysts cannot meet the requirements of high activity and product selectivity at the same time [11]. Currently, Rh-based catalysts are seen as the most promising catalysts for converting syngas into ethanol [12]. However, the performance of single Rh catalysts still does not meeting the required standards, with issues such as high by-products of alkanes and CO2, and low selectivity for ethanol. To address these challenges, researchers have turned to modifying Rh-based catalysts with metallic oxides in order to ameliorate their reaction performance. This modification has also shown promising results in reducing the production of by-products such as CO2 and CH4. Furthermore, the cost-effective approach of enhancing active site numbers by modifying noble Rh-based catalysts with non-precious metal oxides, rather than increasing their loading, has shown promise [13,14]. Therefore, the study of the intrinsic mechanism by which the additives affect the active metals is important for the subsequent development of high-performance catalysts. It has been demonstrated that manganese oxide can oxidize some of the Rh atoms at the Rh-Mn interface, thereby enhancing the insertion of CO [15,16]. Notably, manganese oxide as a very effective modification promoter has excellent performance in stabilizing Rh+ species [17], as well as intermediates and reaction products [18]. A Rh-based bimetallic catalyst with excellent performance in the current literatures is the RhMn@S-1 catalyst with active metal nanoparticles immobilized within zeolite crystals reported by Wang et al. An ethanol yield of 11.6 % was achieved, but due to thermodynamic limitations, the CH4 selectivity was as high as 37.0 %, and the reaction had to be run at a high temperature of 320 °C [19]. In addition, the 2Mn3Rh/CNTs and the Mn-Rh/SiO2 catalysts prepared by liu et al. as well as Yang et al. showed ethanol selectivity of 35.2 % and 7.4 %, respectively, with CO conversion of only 4.0 % and 10.8 %, respectively, and CH4 selectivity was maintained at around 30.0 % [20,21]. In addition to the Mn promoter, the 5Fe-2Rh/TiO2 catalyst prepared by M. Haider et al. and the 2.6La-1.5V-1.5Rh/SiO2 catalyst prepared by N. Subramanian et al. showed ethanol selectivity of 37.2 % and 39.0 %, respectively, but with <10.0 % CO conversion, and a high dosage of precious metals [22,23]. Although extensive research efforts in this area, the efficacy of RhM bimetallic catalysts in producing C2 oxygenates from syngas has shown little enhancement [19]. In addition, the high content of by-products not only restricts the synthesis of target products, but also seriously affects the utilization of carbon resources. Inspiringly, the ethanol yield of our recently prepared 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst was 19.8 %, which is comparable to the performance of Rh-based catalyst previously reported by the group, and the yield far exceeds the Rh-based catalysts for syngas to ethanol reported in the current literatures [24]. But the problems of high by-products, especially the CO2, and low selectivity of ethanol and total alcohols are also prominent. Therefore, on the basis of this typical and simple Rh-based catalyst model, the choice of Mn to discuss the effect of additives on the distribution of Rh species and catalytic performance allows us to both investigate the mechanism of action by which Rh species are promoted and explore the mechanism of influence on the synthesis of by-products. We prepared a series of Rh-Mn catalysts by optimizing the cooperation of Rh and Mn by the spin distillation. Compared with the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, the total alcohol and ethanol selectivity of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 were increased by 26.5 % and 31.3 %, respectively, meanwhile the CO2 selectivity was reduced by 50.4 %. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts The catalysts known as 1RhxMn/TiO2 were synthesized using the technology of spin distillation. Initially, a solution was made by dissolving 10 % Rh(NO3)3 and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (in varying molar ratios) in 60 mL of ethanol. Following this, 5 g of commercially available nano-TiO2, with a very high purity from Degussa, were combined and mixed to ensure complete solution. The mixtures were then sealed with parafilm and stirred continuously at 25 °C for 6 h for sample aging. The solution was later moved to a rotary evaporator and evaporated at 60 °C for 4 h. The resulting product was crushed and inserted into a muffle furnace for calcination at 350 °C for 4 h with a gradual temperature increase of 1 °C per minute. Subsequently, the catalyst was molded and sifted through a 40–60 mesh sieve, and the resulting product was named 1RhxMn/TiO2 (x = 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2 wt%, respectively), where x denotes the Mn content, while Rh content remains constant at 1wt%. In addition, 1RhxMn/TiO2-R denotes the catalyst after reduction. 2.2 Reaction product analysis To analyze the gaseous tail gas of the reaction, it was processed using a GC-950 chromatography system, which was equipped with both TCD and FID detectors. In order to guarantee the data's reliability, product data collection and analysis were performed only after the reaction had reached a steady state, which typically occurred after 24 h. Additionally, the carbon and nitrogen balances of the reaction materials were consistently maintained within the range of 95∼105 %, ensuring the accuracy and precision of the experimental results. The conversion of CO, product selectivity, and yield in the syngas to ethanol reaction can be calculated using the following formula: The conversion of CO : X ( CO ) % = CO ( in ) − CO ( out ) CO ( in ) Product selectivity : S = n i M i M CO , in − M CO , out EtOH yield : Y i e l d E t O H = X ( C O ) × S E t O H Within this specific scenario, the variable ni is utilized to represent the carbon number, Mi is used to indicate the molar quantity of the identified product, and MCO,in and MCO,out are employed to signify the molar quantity of CO at both the entrance and exit. Additionally, CO(in) and CO(out) represent the CO content prior to and subsequent to the reaction process. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic properties The data for the evaluation results of the 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts are displayed in Table 1 . In Fig. 1 a, it is apparent that incorporating the Mn promoter led to an increase in total alcohol selectivity, notably boosting ethanol selectivity while significantly decreasing CO2 selectivity. Specifically, CO conversion, ethanol and total alcohol selectivity show an increasing and then decreasing trend with the Mn content from 0.5 % to 2 % at the reaction temperature of 250 °C (Table 1 and Table S1). The highest ethanol selectivity and CO conversion are obtained when Mn content is 1 %, which increases the total alcohol selectivity from 57.0 % to 72.1 % and ethanol selectivity from 35.5 % to 46.6 %, while reducing CO2 selectivity from 27.4 % to 13.6 % compared with that of the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst without the Mn promoter. But the impact of Mn on CH4 and C2+HC selectivity is minimal, remaining around 8.0 % and 2.0 % respectively when the Mn content is changed from 0.5 % to 2 %. In addition, Fig. 1b and Table S3 summarized some of the previously reported catalysts for ethanol production from syngas with Rh as the main active metal. The ethanol yield of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 is 24.1 %, which is the highest among the Rh-based catalysts reported for syngas to ethanol. And it showed good stability with no significant deactivation in 200 h (Fig. 1c). Fig. 1d illustrates the activation energies for CO conversion of typical 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst and 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst obtained by temperature and CO conversion, and follow the following order: 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 (69.4 kJ mol-1) > 1Rh/TiO2 (32.3 kJ mol-1), which is consistent with the catalytic activity (Table 1), indicating that the activation of CO on 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 is suppressed compared to 1Rh/TiO2 (Fig. 1d). 3.2 Physicochemical properties and crystal structure of catalysts The surface structure of 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts was analyzed in order to reveal the differences in STE reaction performance. The N2 adsorption-desorption isothermal curve and the aperture size of the 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 . It is evident that all catalysts, regardless of the Mn content variations, emerge typical type IV isotherms along with H2-type hysteresis loops (Fig. 2a). This observation is significant as it indicates the presence of mesopores within the catalysts, which also exhibit a uniform pore size distribution. Additionally, Fig. 2b further corroborates this mesoporous structure by presenting a aperture distribution that is predominantly concentrated around 15 nm. Table S4 shows the SBET, pore sizes and pore volumes of 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts. With the increase of Mn content from 0.5 % to 2 %, the changes of SBET and pore size are not significant, which may be mainly due to the fact that the low loading of Rh and Mn is not enough to cause large changes in the surface structure of the catalyst. Among all the catalysts, the 1Rh1.5Mn/TiO2 catalyst exhibits the largest SBET, but its catalytic performance and ethanol selectivity are poor. The above analysis of surface structure indicates that the outstanding performance of the catalyst is not directly associated with the SBET and pore structure. Furthermore, X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD) test was conducted to examine the impact of Mn modification on the catalyst crystal structure. As illustrated in Fig. S1, all catalysts exhibit characteristic diffraction peaks of the support, with no characteristic diffraction peaks of Rh-Mn. This lack of peaks may be put down to either the high decentralization of the active metal on the support or the active metal being loaded below detection thresholds. The results from high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) reveal that the catalyst's morphology remains largely unchanged with the increase of Mn content from 0 % to 2.0 % (see Fig. S2). And the morphology of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is consistently preserved both before and after reduction. Therefore, combining BET, XRD and HR-TEM characterization, the modification of Mn has no significant effect on the surface structure, crystal structure and morphology of the catalyst. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images and the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2-R catalyst can be seen in Fig. 3 , which indicate that RhMn may mainly exist in the form of clusters and the cluster particle size is around 1.2 nm (Fig. 3a-d). In addition, the EDX spectra show that both Rh and Mn signals appear in the same region, which further proves the formation of RhMn clusters (Fig. 3e-f). The corresponding elemental mapping images show a uniform distribution of Rh, Mn on the catalyst surface (Fig. 3g). The above results indicate that the introduction of Mn has a minimal effect on the crystal phase of catalysts. Consequently, Mn is likely to function as an electronic promoter. It is necessary to continue to explore the effect of Mn modification on the electronic environment around the active center of the catalyst as well as the change of active species on the catalyst surface. 3.3 XPS To investigate whether Mn functions as an electronic modifier influencing the composition and oxidation state on the catalyst surface, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a typical 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the Rh 3d5/2 binding energy, which is measured at 309.2 eV in the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4a), can be attributed to Rh3+ [25]. This indicates that Rh3+ is the predominant Rh species before H2 reduction. In the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2-R catalyst, the Rh 3d5/2 binding energy is detected at 307.6 eV and 308.9 eV, respectively (Fig. 4c), attributed to Rh0 and Rh+. This suggests that Rh0 and Rh+ are the major Rh species after H2 reduction. Compared with the 1Rh/TiO2-R catalyst without the introduction of Mn (Fig. 4b), the peak area of Rh+ located at around 308.9 eV is significantly increased, while the peak area of Rh0 located at around 307.6 eV is significantly decreased for the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2-R catalyst with the addition of the additive Mn. This indicates that the addition of Mn adjusts the relative amount between Rh+ and Rh0, resulting in an increase of Rh+ and a decrease of Rh0, i.e., an increase in Rh+/Rh0 ratio after the addition of Mn. The local Rh ion content of all catalysts obtained by XPS is shown in Table S5 and Fig. S3. Obviously, the Rh+/Rh0 ratio is consistent with the changes in ethanol selectivity and shows the following trend: Rh+/Rh0(1Rh1Mn/TiO2) > Rh+/Rh0(1Rh0.5Mn/TiO2) > Rh+/Rh0(1Rh1.5Mn/TiO2) > Rh+/Rh0(1Rh2Mn/TiO2) > Rh+/Rh0(1Rh/TiO2). Literature [26] showed that Rh0 promotes CO dissociation and Rh+ promotes CO insertion reaction, a high concentration of Rh+ can enhance ethanol selectivity, while a low concentration of Rh0 reduces CO conversion. Hence, the findings presented in Table 1 indicate a decline in the CO conversion and an increase in ethanol selectivity following the introduction of the Mn additive. This observation aligns with the outcomes of the XPS analysis. The XPS data reveals that Mn functions as an electron promoter, altering the reducibility of the Rh active species, consequently improving the efficiency of the STE process. 3.4 H2-TPR The effect of Mn on the reduction behavior was further investigated through a hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment. In Fig. 5 a, the peaks located between 75 and 125 °C are attributed to the reduction of Rh3+ to Rh+ and the peaks located between 130 and 250 °C are related to the reduction of Rh+ to Rh0 [27]. With the introduction of Mn, there is a noticeable move in the peak temperature towards a higher temperature in the high-temperature region. This suggests that the emergence of Mn hinders the reduction of Rh+ to Rh0, which is important as Rh+ plays a significant role in ethanol production [26]. From Table S6, it also can be observed that the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst has the largest peak area for hydrogen consumption at high temperature. This is due to the fact that the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst has the highest concentration of Rh+ resulting in a greater consumption of hydrogen. In contrast, the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst exhibits the smallest high-temperature hydrogen consumption peak area, indicating that the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst has the lowest Rh+ content on it. This H2-TPR results are consistent with the XPS results, i.e., the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst has the highest Rh+/Rh0 ratio and the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst has the lowest Rh+/Rh0 ratio. 3.5 CO-DRIFTS The catalyst's active site and the adsorption behavior of CO reactant species were analyzed through a CO-DRIFTS test focused on CO adsorption. The peaks observed at 2094 and 2026 cm-1 in Fig. 5b correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric carbonyl stretch vibrations of gem‑dicarbonyl CO adsorption [CO(gdc)] [28]. This form is created through the chemical adsorption of CO on the Rh+ site [29,30], which influences the insertion of CO. Additionally, the peak in the 1900–1800 cm-1 scope is likely due to the bridge-bonded CO [CO(b)], formed through the chemical adsorption of CO at the Rh0 site [31]. As illustrated in Fig. 5b, the CO(gdc) peak area exhibits a pronounced increase following the addition of Mn on 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst. The CO(gdc) peak area of 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is the largest, which indicates that 1 % Mn is the most effective in promoting the insertion of CO relative to other 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts. The 1Rh0.5Mn/TiO2 and 1Rh1.5Mn/TiO2 catalysts exhibit the next largest CO(gdc) peak areas, while the 1Rh2Mn/TiO2 and 1Rh/TiO2 catalysts exhibit the smallest CO(gdc) peak areas. Its order of magnitude is consistent with the changes in ethanol selectivity. Furthermore, Table S7 reveals that the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst has a larger CO(b) peak area within the range of 1900–1800 cm-1 in comparison to the other catalysts, which suggests that the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst contains a higher concentration of Rh0. The CO-DRIFTS finds are also corroborated by the XPS and H2-TPR results, i.e., the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst possesses the highest Rh+ content, while the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst possesses the highest Rh0 content. 3.6 CO-TPD The CO programmed temperature-raising desorption (CO-TPD) test was conducted to study more comprehensively the types of CO molecules adsorbed by the catalysts. The findings, depicted in Fig. 5c, where the desorption peaks between 50 and 150 °C are attributed to linearly bonded CO[CO(l)] [32,33]. The CO(l) species are generated by the chemisorption of CO at the Rh0 site, Rh0 affects the dissociation of CO. As can be seen from Table S8, the CO(l) desorption peak areas of the 1Rh/TiO2, 1Rh0.5Mn/TiO2 and 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalysts do not vary much from each other, but the CO(l) desorption peak area decreases significantly when the addition of Mn is over 1 %, indicating that the adsorption of CO by the catalysts will be inhibited if the content of Mn is too high, thus affecting the conversion of CO. This can be intuitively seen from the performance evaluation data. In addition, the peak temperature of the CO desorption peak shifts to a lower temperature after the addition of Mn and shows the following trend: 1Rh0.5Mn/TiO2(128 °C) > 1Rh/TiO2(122 °C) > 1Rh1Mn/TiO2(117 °C) > 1Rh1.5Mn/TiO2(107 °C) > 1Rh2Mn/TiO2(103 °C). It is shown that the excess addition of Mn weakens the catalyst adsorption of CO, thereby inhibiting the catalyst's activation of CO. This is consistent with the results of performance evaluation. 3.7 CO-TPSR To clarify the impact of Mn modification on Rh-based catalysts during CO dissociation and hydrogenation, the CO programmed temperature-raising surface reaction (CO-TPSR) test was conduct. As illustrated in Fig. 5d, the peaks observed between 100 and 200 °C are attributed to the CH4 peaks. The level of the peak temperature represents the dissociation capacity of the CO molecule. The CH4 peak is moved to a higher temperature range after the introduction of Mn, indicating that Mn's addition attenuates the dissociation capacity of Rh species for CO molecules [15,34,35]. Nevertheless, from Table S9, it can be noted that the CH4 peak areas across all catalysts display a volcano-shaped distribution. The level of CH4 peak area represents the number of active sites dissociated by the CO molecule [32]. Among these catalysts, the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst has the largest CH4 peak area (i.e., the highest CH4 generation). This implies that the appropriate amount of Mn enhances the number of active sites for CO dissociation on the 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalyst. In contrast, an excess of Mn reduces the number of active sites for CO dissociation on the 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts, leading to a decline in catalyst activity, which is similar to the results of the CO-TPD and CO conversion. Furthermore, the CH4 peak intensities of all the catalysts can also be observed in a volcano-shaped distribution from Table S9. The level of CH4 peak intensity represents the CO hydrogenation capacity [36,37]. The CH4 peak intensity of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is the greatest among all the catalysts. So, the incorporation of a modest quantity of Mn enhances the CO hydrogenation capacity of 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts, whereas, an excess of Mn impairs the CO hydrogenation capacity of 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts. 3.8 CO hydrogenation mechanism To further explain the process of converting syngas into ethanol on a 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst, we used in-situ DRIFTS analysis at 250 °C to track surface intermediates during the CO hydrogenation (Fig. 6 a). The peaks detected at 2961, 2926, and 2870 cm-1 are CH x species. Specifically, the peak at 2961 cm-1 represents the asymmetric stretching of CH3 species, while the peaks at 2926 and 2870 cm-1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of CH2 species [38,39]. The band at 1659 cm-1 indicates the CO stretching vibration of the CHO group. Furthermore, signals at 1571 and 1368 cm-1 suggest the presence of CH3COO groups. The formation of CH3CO group is suggested by the presence of CH3COO species. This is because the CH3COO species can result from the interaction between CH3CO group and TiO2 carriers [19]. The peak at 1435 cm-1 belongs to CH3CHO group. As a comparison, the Fig. 6a shows the peaks of CH x and CH3CHO, CH3COO species are almost invisible on the 1Mn/TiO2 catalyst, suggesting that CH x and CH3CHO, CH3CO are one of the intermediates in the ethanol synthesis process from syngas. Furthermore, it can be observed from Fig. 6b, the peak intensities of CH x and CH3CHO species exhibit a notable increase with the progression of the reaction, thereby confirming the pivotal role of CH x and CH3CHO as the primary intermediates in the ethanol production process from syngas over the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst. For the phenomenon that the intensity of CH x peaks decreases significantly after the addition of 1 % Mn on 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, while the intensity of peaks of species CH3COO and CH3CHO increases significantly. We speculate that the reason is mainly due to the fact that the insertion of CO is facilitated, which in turn facilitates the process of CH x combining with CO to form CH3CO as well as CH3CHO. 3.9 CO conversion-CO2 selectivity curve In order to elucidate the reason that the addition of Mn on 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst made the CO2 selectivity decrease dramatically, the CO2 programmed temperature-raising desorption (CO2-TPD) test was conducted. As shown in Fig. 6c, the peaks appearing at 50–150 °C and 250–350 °C belong to the CO2 desorption peaks. By comparing the typical 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst and 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, it is found that the area of the CO2 desorption peaks of the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst is significantly larger than that of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which indicates that the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst exhibits greater adsorptive capacity for CO2 than 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, and the re-adsorbed CO2 may be consumed during the reaction process through the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS). The 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, due to its weak adsorption capacity for CO2, allows the resulting CO2 to be discharged with the product. In addition, we further elucidated the reason for the decrease in CO2 selectivity by means of CO conversion-CO2 selectivity curves (Fig. 6d). The relationship between CO conversion and CO2 selectivity can be obtained by adjusting the gas flow rate while maintaining a constant H2/CO ratio (Table S10 and Table S11). In the CO conversion-CO2 selectivity curve, the CO2 selectivity extrapolated toward the axial intercept is attributed to primary CO2 (CO* + O* → CO2), asterisks indicate chemisorption) and the slope of the curve responds to the rate of CO2 production by the WGS reaction [40]. As can be seen from Fig. 6d, the primary CO2 selectivity of the 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst is about 25.0 %, whereas the primary CO2 selectivity of the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is about 6.0 %, and the larger slope of the curve obtained on 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 indicates that 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 is favorable for water gas reaction. Thus the CO2 reduction is mainly due to the inhibition of the CO + O → CO2 step, and the RWGS may also has a small contribution. 3.10 Reaction pathways Combining the above findings and previous studies on the mechanism, we proposed a probable reaction pathway for syngas to ethanol over 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 7 ). Upon dissociation of some of the adsorbed CO, C hydrogenates to CH x species, while O reacts with some of the non-dissociated adsorbed CO to form CO2 (CO + O → CO2). The O may also continue to react with hydrogen to form water, which in turn results in a WGS reaction. The CO2 produced by the reaction may also react with activated H2 in the RWGS. The adsorbed CO may continue to be hydrogenated to produce CH x O species, and CH x O continues to be hydrogenated to produce CH3OH. There are two conversion paths for CH x species, one path is for CH x to react with partially non-dissociatively adsorbed CO to produce CH3CO, which subsequently undergoes hydrogenation to ethanol. The other path is that CH x combines with CHO species to produce CH3CHO, which also continues to hydrogenate to produce ethanol. And the continues hydrogenation of CH x species produces hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the continued hydrogenation of CH3CO also results in the formation of CH3CHO species, therefore the CH x and CH3CHO are the more significant intermediates for ethanol synthesis, which is also confirmed by the results from syn-DRIFTS. 4 Conclusion In summary, the STE performance of 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts is linked to the relative content of Mn. Under the condition of maintaining the high activity, compared with the unpromoted 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst, the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst showed the most excellent performance, with an increase in ethanol selectivity from 35.5 % to 46.6 % and a decrease in the selectivity of the main byproduct of CO2, from 27.4 % to 13.6 %, and exhibited good stability. H2-TPR and XPS results demonstrated that Rh+ was the main Rh species for the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst, whereas Rh0 was the main Rh species for the unpromoted 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst. DRIFTS spectra showed that the content of the key intermediates for ethanol synthesis, CH3CHO and CH3CO, increased with the addition of Mn. The Mn in 1RhxMn/TiO2 catalysts inhibited the reduction of Rh+ to Rh0, resulting in an increase in the relative content of Rh+, which enhanced the CO insertion reaction and further increased the ethanol selectivity. Besides, the intensification of CO insertion reaction weakened the process of CO + O → CO2, leading to a decrease in CO2 production. coredata.dc:description: Significant strides have been undertaken to catalyze the production of ethanol from syngas, yet the challenge remains in developing catalysts that simultaneously exhibit high activity and selectivity. In this study, we designed a high-performance Rh-Mn catalyst. The CO conversion of finally screened 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst is 51.8 %, and the total alcohol selectivity and ethanol yield are 72.1 % and 24.1 % respectively. This is the highest ethanol yield reported to date for Rh-based catalysts. Additionally, this catalyst also kept good stability. The outstanding performance is attributed to the fact that Mn facilitates the formation of Rh+ active sites, the process of CO insertion, and the generation of CH3CHO and CH3CO species—critical intermediates in ethanol production. In contrast, the unpromoted 1Rh/TiO2 catalyst showed poor ethanol selectivity and mainly produced the Rh0 species, whereas the 1Rh1Mn/TiO2 catalyst with the addition of Mn showed an increase in total alcohol and ethanol selectivity of 26.5 % and 31.3 %, respectively, as well as a reduction in CO2 of 50.4 %. In addition, we elucidated the CO2 generation and conversion pathways in the syngas to ethanol process, which is important for the effective utilization of carbon resources.
